overview: Over 14 weeks, our team of five UX designers was tasked with identifying and addressing a real-world issue through an interactive digital prototype. We explored how to reduce consumer waste by creating a system that connects donors with NGOs, ensuring reusable items are efficiently redistributed. The project required us to apply design thinking—from user research and prototyping to usability testing and evaluation—to develop an impactful, scalable solution.
para0: div[{H1[Drop It Off – Reducing Waste Through Smarter Donations]}{p-em[An interactive prototype designed to streamline the donation process, ensuring reusable items reach the right recipients while reducing landfill waste.]}],h3[The challenge],p[Despite many consumers wanting to donate their unwanted items responsibly, 85% of donation bin contents still end up in landfills due to sorting inefficiencies and misdirected donations. At the same time, smaller community-driven organizations and NGOs struggle to obtain necessary donations, lacking visibility and structured systems for receiving items. Businesses, though often willing to donate surplus goods, face logistical challenges that lead them to default to wasteful disposal methods.],h3[Our solution],div[{p[Drop It Off bridges this gap by creating a donation-matching system that:]}{ul.col[Connects donors with NGOs actively seeking specific items.;Improves transparency in donation distribution.;Reduces waste by redistributing reusable items more effectively.]}],h3[Impact summary],p[{ul.col[71.4 SUS Score → Above-average usability score, validating the platform’s core functionality with room for refinement.;Encouraging donor adoption through transparency → Showing where donations go helps donors emotionally connect with causes, increasing willingness to donate.;Usability challenges in scaling adoption →  Strong early engagement, but onboarding and feature discoverability need refinement for long-term adoption.;Future scalability → The NGO and business-facing interface requires further development to support inventory management and large-scale donation logistics.]}{em[*As an early-stage iteration, this design cycle has validated the platform’s usefulness. However, further UI refinement and testing are needed to ensure a frictionless user experience and maximize long-term impact.]}]
para2: h2[Research & Discovery],div[{p[We first identified consumer waste as our situation of use, focusing on why donations were being misdirected or discarded. To map out key influences in this ecosystem, we established five main stakeholder groups:]}{ul.col[Consumers: Individuals trying to donate items or discard them.;Charity Workers & NGOs: Organisations managing donations but facing logistical challenges.;People in Need: Beneficiaries reliant on donations for essential items.;Circular Economy Services: Platforms facilitating second-hand sales and exchanges.;Retail Industry: Businesses generating surplus items with potential for donation.]}{p[To ensure high usefulness, we conducted interviews with representatives across three of these groups, using their insights to refine our assumptions and identify critical pain points.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP0a-stakeholders-main.jpg{main stakeholders in the situation of consumer waste;The initial rich picture, captioning the main stakeholders: consumers, retail industry (consumer industry), charity workers, people in need, and circular economy services.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP0b-rich-picture.jpg{rich picture;Initial rich picture with assumptions of the stakeholders’ needs and wants with annotated complimentary— and clashing statements (red and green lines).}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP0c-stakeholders.jpg{nuanced map of stakeholders;A more nuanced map of all the stakeholders, with annotations on who we interviewed.}]{more nuanced representations of stakeholders;}}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP2-rich-picture.png{detailed, final rich picture;Detailed rich picture with overview of stakeholders’ presumed and observed wants and needs with annotated complimentary and clashing statements.}]}]
